params.text:
Integrated Pest Management

      Integrated pest management (IPM) is when pest is managed by using various methods or tactics to minimize the use of chemical pesticides.  IPM methods are cultural, physical, mechanical, biological, and policy and quarantine regulations. Regular monitoring of the condition of the crop is a key to successful pest management. Knowledge on the pests is important aspect to identify what method is the best to use.

 

Destructive stage of in pests of bitter gourd and its control measures.

items.description:
APHIDS (Aphids gossypii - cotton aphids), (Myzus persicae – green peach aphids), (Aphis fabae – bean aphid)

 

DESTRUCTIVE STAGE

Sometimes vectors of viral diseases of crops. Destructive stages are adults and nymphs. 

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Remove weeds and volunteer plants.

  • Spray botanical extracts (kakawate, hot pepper, lantana, ginger).

  • Spray with dishwashing liquid detergent. 

  • Use beneficial insects like parasitic wasps and lady beetles which prey on aphids. 

  • Use yellow sticky trap. 

  • Remove immediately the infested plant part. 

  • Spray insecticide if necessary.

FRUIT FLY (Bactrocera cucurbitae Coquillet)

 

DESTRUCTIVE STAGE

The most destructive insect pest of cucumber and other cucurbits.  The adult lays eggs on the female flowers, stems, and fruits.  Destructive at fruiting stage.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Observe proper sanitation.

  • Use clear plastic bagging.

  • Use fruit fly attractant. 

  • Fruit bagging.

  • Spray insecticide if necessary.

params.alt: Leaf footed bugs of Bitter gourd

items.description:
LEAF FOOTED BUGS (Leptolossus sp.)

 

DESTRUCTIVE STAGE

It emits unpleasant odor when disturbed. The infested fruit is deformed at early stage.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Irrigate the crop twice a week to prevent or minimize drying of the leaves sucked by the pests.

LEAF FOLDER/CUCUMBER MOTH/COTTON CATERPILLAR (Diaphania indica (Saunders)

 

DESTRUCTIVE STAGE

The destructive larva is greenish with two white stripes at the back.  Damaged leaves become lace-like patches, skeletonized and become brownish with web bed and tapering edge.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Handpick larvae and kill.

  • Spray insecticides if necessary.

THRIPS (Thrips tabaci – onion thrips), (Thrips palmi  Karny – melon thrips)

 

DESTRUCTIVE STAGE

Nymphs and adults are the damaging stages which cause silvering then browning of the leaves.

Vectors of tospovirus (watermelon silver mottle virus/WsMov, tomato spotted wilt virus /TSWV, melon necrotic spot virus /MNSV, melon yellow spot virus /MYSV, and iris yellow spot virus/IYSV.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Proper land preparation.

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Remove infested leaves and dispose properly.

  • Remove weeds and volunteer plants.

  • Use plastic mulch to repel. 

  • Spray insecticide if necessary.

WHITE FLY (Bemsia tabaci)

 

DESTRUCTIVE STAGE

It is a serious pest of other crops and acts a vector of viral diseases (begomovirus). Malformation of leaves if there is severe infestation. Destructive stages are adults and nymphs.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Use yellow sticky traps.

  • Remove weeds.

  • Spray insecticidal soaps or neem oil.

  • Spray chemical insecticide if necessary.

LEAF WORM (Aulocophora similes)

 

DESTRUCTIVE STAGE

It is a common foliage feeder of bitter gourd and also feeds on fruit leaving scars.  Severe damage is observed at seedling stage if not managed immediately. But it is manageable at vegetative stage of the crop.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Remove infested fruit and dispose properly.

  • Spray insecticides if necessary.
